{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Harold Jones | image_name = File:Harold_Jones_Abergavenny_1921.jpg | image_size = 146x203px | image_alt = | image_caption = Mugshot of Harold Jones, taken 14 November 1921 | birth_name = | birth_date = 11 January 1906 | birth_place = [[Abertillery]], Wales | death_date = 1971 | death_place = [[London]], England | cause = [[Bone cancer]] | alias = | motive = {{flatlist| * [[Rape]] (Freda Burnell) * [[Thrill killing]] (Florence Little) }} | charge = [[Murder]] | conviction = Murder | conviction_penalty = Detained at [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|His Majesty's pleasure]] | conviction_status = Released 6 December 1941 | occupation = Store assistant | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Harold Jones''' (11 January 1906 – 1971)<ref>''Exposing Jack the Stripper: A Biography of the Worst Serial Killer You've Probably Never Heard Of'' {{ISBN|978-1-492-21043-6}} p. 177</ref> was a [[child murder]]er who committed the murder of two [[preadolescence|preadolescent]] girls in [[Monmouthshire (historic)|Monmouthshire]], [[Wales]] in 1921 when he himself was aged 15.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Every_Mother_s_Nightmare.html?id=0y9JXwAACAAJ|title=Every Mother's Nightmare: Abertillery in Mourning|last=Milkins|first=Neil|date=2016-11-26|publisher=Old Bakehouse Publications|isbn=9781905967117|language=en}}</ref>
Jones was acquitted of the murder of his first victim, 8-year-old Freda Burnell,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1OFiCgAAQBAJ&lpg=PT134&dq=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&pg=PT134#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&f=false|title=The Who's Who of British Crime|last=Morris|first=Jim|date=2015-05-15|publisher=Amberley Publishing Limited|isbn=9781445639352|language=en}}</ref> at Monmouthshire Assizes on 21 June 1921. Just 17 days later, he murdered an 11-year-old neighbour named Florence Little. Jones pleaded guilty to Little's murder; also confessing to having murdered Freda Burnell at this second trial.<ref name=":0" />
Owing to his being under 16 at the time he committed the murders, Jones escaped [[Capital punishment in the United Kingdom|capital punishment]] for his crimes; instead being sentenced to be detained at [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|His Majesty's pleasure]] on 1 November 1921.<ref name=":0" /> Jones was released from prison in 1941, later marrying and fathering a child.<ref name=":0" /> He died of [[bone cancer]] in 1971.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.southwalesargus.co.uk/news/4206050.Gwent_author_s_new_theory_on_murders|title=Gwent Author's New Theory on Murders|access-date=29 September 2018|newspaper=South Wales Argus|date=16 March 2009}}</ref>
==Early life== Harold Jones was born in the Welsh [[company town|colliery town]] of [[Abertillery]] in 1906, the eldest of four children born into a poor family. His father, Phillip,<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 85</ref> worked as a coal miner, whereas his mother was a housewife.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 86</ref> Jones and his siblings attended a local council school where he was regarded as a popular and exemplary student, showing a particular flair for sports, and holding aspirations to become a professional boxer.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 86</ref> He is also known to have spent much of his free time reading, and to have occasionally played the [[Organ (music)#Church organs|organ]] at local church services.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 73</ref>
Jones left school at 14 to obtain employment—largely as a means of supplementing his family's income. He found employment at a local oil and seed merchant named Mortimer's Stores. Here, he was known to be a punctual and trustworthy employee who was both capable of managing the shop without help, and popular with customers.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} pp. 86-87</ref>
==Murders== ===Freda Burnell=== On the afternoon of 5 February 1921, an eight-year-old girl named Freda Burnell was reported missing by her parents. She had last been seen by her father, Fred,<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 177</ref> at approximately 9 a.m. that morning, having been sent on an errand from her home at 9 Earl Street to purchase poultry spice and grit from Mortimer's Stores in nearby Somerset Street to feed the family livestock, with her father promising her a [[penny]] upon her return.<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 177</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-45044159|title=Murdered Abertillery Girl's Niece Learnt About Tragedy in Book|access-date=8 September 2018|newspaper=BBC.co.uk|date=4 August 2018}}</ref>
When Freda had not returned home after an hour, her frantic parents began making inquiries, including at the store Freda had been sent to visit. The 15-year-old assistant at this store, Harold Jones, confirmed to Freda's father (and later the police) that Freda had visited the store at approximately 9:05 a.m. and that he had served her a bag of poultry spice, adding that she had also asked for a bag of poultry grit but he had informed her the store only had loose poultry grit.<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' {{ISBN|978-0-747-23731-0}} p. 232</ref> The child, he claimed, had left the store to ask her father whether loose poultry grit would suffice, and he had not seen her since.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 79</ref> By 3 p.m., the Burnell family had informed police Freda was missing, and an exhaustive search for the child was launched.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 78</ref>
The following morning, Freda's body was found by a collier concealed in a sack in an alleyway just 300 yards from the store she had visited.{{refn|group=n|A workman would inform investigators he had passed the precise spot where Freda's body was discovered just 15 minutes before the collier had discovered her body, and was adamant the sack had not been there, thus making the most likely time the body had been deposited at this location sometime between 7:15 a.m. and 7:30 a.m.}} Her cause of death was certified as being a combination of [[blunt trauma]] to her head and [[strangulation]] evident via a cord still tied around her neck, with the time of death occurring between 9:30 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. on the date of her disappearance.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Murder of Freda Burnell |date=12 July 1921 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/63196040 |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref> In addition, Freda had been gagged, her elbows had been bound behind her back, and her ankles were knotted together. An attempt had also been made to rape the child.<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 177</ref> Traces of [[Husk|corn chaff]] were also found upon and around her body, and inside the sack in which she was discovered.<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' {{ISBN|978-0-747-23731-0}} pp. 232-233</ref>{{refn|group=n|As per standard procedure, Abertillery Police contacted [[Scotland Yard]] to supervise the murder investigation. Detective [[Chief inspector#United Kingdom|Chief Inspector]] Albert Heldon and Detective Sergreant Alfred Soden arrived in the town on 7 February to supervise the investigation.}}
Investigators noted that a chicken run in the shed belonging to Harold Jones's employers located just a few hundred yards<ref>{{cite news|title=The Murder of Freda Burnell |date=12 July 1921 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/63196040 |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref> from where the body had been discovered had corn chaff extensively scattered upon the ground, and a handkerchief known to have been in Freda's possession at the time of her disappearance was also found on the ground in the shed. In addition, an axe handle determined to have caused the blunt trauma to Freda's head was discovered concealed beneath some sacking inside the shed. Aside from his employers, Jones was the only individual in possession of a key to the shed, and investigators established a clear time frame of between 9:15 and 9:40 a.m. when no witnesses had physically seen him inside the store.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 84</ref> {{quote box | quote = "Halfway down the lane, Harold said: 'You wait here while I go down to the shed.' Harold walked on alone, turned and whispered loudly, 'You lot keep quiet!' ... Harold went into the shed ... when he came out, he locked the shed door and came back to us whispering, 'Keep quiet, keep quiet.'" | source = Levi Meyrick's statement to police describing Harold Jones's actions between 10:20 p.m. and 10:30 p.m. on 5 February 1921.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 74</ref> | width = 32em }} A friend of Jones named Levi Meyrick also informed police Jones had actively dissuaded him and a friend from accompanying him to the storage shed at approximately 10:20 p.m. on 5 February; another [[witness]] also informed police he had heard a female child's screams emanating from this shed on the actual morning of Freda's disappearance.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Murder of Freda Burnell |date=12 July 1921 |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/63196040 |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au|accessdate=9 September 2018}}</ref> When questioned as to these facts, Jones insisted he had not been in the shed on the day of Freda's disappearance. Nonetheless, investigators were convinced otherwise, and he was held in detention at Abertillery Police Station to await the coutcome of the [[coroner#inquest|coroner's inquest]].{{refn|group=n|At the time of the statement in question, Levi Meyrick had accompanied Harold Jones as he walked to his employer's shed to retrieve a sack of potatoes scheduled to be delivered to a customer the following morning. When Meyrick and his friend asked Jones why he had not retrieved the potatoes from the shed Upon his return, Jones simply replied, "I'll pick them up in the morning."}}
The [[inquest]] into the death of Freda Burnell was formally opened on 7 March.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 84</ref> Jones was one of many individuals called to testify at this inquest. He performed poorly on the stand; repeatedly giving conflicting testimony as to his actions on the day of the murder and being forced to admit to lying about various aspects of his testimony (on one occasion prompting the [[coroner]] to scold him and insist he tell the truth).<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 84</ref> Nonetheless, despite there being little [[real evidence|physical evidence]] linking Jones to the murder, investigators believed enough [[circumstantial evidence]] existed to formally charge him with the crime. In response to this formal charge, Jones replied: "I know it looks black against me, but I never done it."<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 75</ref> He was remanded in custody until 5 April when he appeared before magistrates. On this date, a decision to try Jones for the [[wilful murder]] of Freda Burnell was reached. Bail was refused, and he was detained at [[HM Prison Usk|Usk Prison]] to await trial.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 84</ref>
===Initial trial=== Jones was brought to trial for the murder of Freda Burnell at Monmouthshire Assizes on 21 June,<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 177</ref> the prosecution [[allegation|alleging]] that he had murdered Freda inside the shed belonging to his employers on the morning of 5 February before placing her body in a sack, and placing the body in an alley close to the shed that evening.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-45044159|title=Murdered Abertillery Girl's Niece Learnt About Tragedy in Book|access-date=10 September 2018|newspaper=BBC.co.uk|date=4 August 2018}}</ref><ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} pp. 84-85</ref> He pleaded [[Plea#Guilty and not guilty pleas|not guilty]] to the charge; insisting that he had last seen Freda when he had served her at approximately 9:05 a.m. before she had left the store.
Although Jones had contradicted himself on several occasions at the initial inquest, he remained calm when called to testify in his own defence at trial, also withstanding rigorous cross-examination. His employer, Herbert Henry Mortimer, provided him with an alibi; insisting he had heard Jones and his own son working in the store in the early morning of 5 February before the two had been sent to deliver a sack of potatoes to a customer at approximately 10 a.m., later returning to the store where they had continued to work for the rest of the day. Furthermore, on the third day of the trial Jones's own father challenged the prosecutor's contention his son had placed Freda's body in the alley on the evening of her murder; insisting his son had not left the family home between the time he had returned home from work and the following morning, and that he would likely have known so had this been the case. His testimony was [[corroborating evidence|corroborated]] by his wife, who also stressed her son had always exhibited "good behaviour" towards young girls.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 85</ref>
Despite the evidence presented at this trial clearly indicating that Freda had most likely been killed in the shed belonging to Jones's employers and only Harold and the Mortimer family having access to the key, after deliberating for over five hours,<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 75</ref> the jury found Jones not guilty of Freda's murder, returning a unanimous verdict<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' {{ISBN|978-0-747-23731-0}} pp. 232-233</ref> of murder by person or persons unknown.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 83</ref>
Jones walked free from the courtroom to a private and reportedly tearful reunion with his parents before being escorted to a local restaurant for a meal. At this service, Jones stood upon a table and addressed his numerous supporters<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 76</ref> with a speech in which he stated: "I thank you all. I do not hold a grudge against the people of Abertillery for the horrendous ordeal I have been put through."<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 86</ref> He subsequently returned to Abertillery in a [[charabanc]] adorned with flags and bunting to cheers from the local public, most of whom found the notion that a 15-year-old boy could sexually assault and kill a child simply inconceivable.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68StTYAvpn8C&lpg=PA75&dq=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&f=false|title=Foul Deeds and Suspicious Deaths in Newport|last=Underwood|first=Terry|date=2004-09-01|publisher=Casemate Publishers|isbn=9781903425596|language=en}}</ref><ref>''A Question of Evidence: The Casebook of Great Forensic Controversies, from Napoleon to O.J.'' {{ISBN|0-471-44014-0}} p. 139</ref> One of those to greet Jones upon his return was a neighbour named George Little, who greeted him with the statement: "Well done, lad. We knew you didn't do it."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/lifestyle/nostalgia/how-welsh-child-murderer-become-14568644|title=How a Welsh Child Murderer May Have Become one of London's Most Notorious Serial Killers|access-date=21 September 2018|newspaper=walesonline.co.uk|date=26 April 2018}}</ref>
===Florence Little=== Seventeen days after Jones's acquittal of Freda's murder, on 8 July, he observed a neighbour of his named Florence Little playing [[hopskotch]] with his own sister, Flossie, outside his home at 10 Darran Road.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 76</ref> He lured Florence into his house on the pretext of asking her to perform an errand for his family. Inside Jones's home, Florence was instantly partially strangled and dragged into the kitchen,<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68StTYAvpn8C&lpg=PA75&dq=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&pg=PA75#v=onepage&q=%22harold%20jones%22%20murder&f=false|title=Foul Deeds and Suspicious Deaths in Newport|last=Underwood|first=Terry|date=2004-09-01|publisher=Casemate Publishers|isbn=9781903425596|language=en}}</ref> where she was beaten across the head and temple with a plank of wood before Jones suspended her head and neck over his sink, grabbed her by the hair, and proceeded to cut her throat with his father's [[pocketknife]].<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' {{ISBN|978-0-747-23731-0}} p. 233</ref> He then wrapped Florence's head and neck in a grey army shirt before concealing her partially dressed body in the family attic. Having washed all the bloodstains he noted from the sink, walls, floor, and entrance hatch to the attic, Jones then proceeded to bathe himself.{{refn|group=n|Jones would subsequently inform his family that the reason he had washed his own clothes on the date of Florence's murder was because he had accidentally dropped them in the bath.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/28007232|title=A Welsh Horror. Two little Girls Murdered; A Boy's Confession|access-date=8 September 2018|newspaper=nla.gov.au|date=3 November 1921}}</ref>}}
Police were notified of Florence's disappearance at 11:15 p.m., and immediately conducted house-to-house searches. The simultaneous searches of nearby woodland and mountains would be assisted by hundreds of local volunteers including Harold Jones.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 77</ref> Questioned by police as to whether he had seen Florence on the day of her disappearance, Jones repeated the same lie he had earlier recited to Mrs. Little when she had called upon his house asking as to her daughter's whereabouts: that she had been at his front door, but had then simply "ran off."<ref>''The Encyclopedia of Serial Killers'' {{ISBN|978-0-747-23731-0}} p. 233</ref>{{refn|group=n|Following Jones's acquittal of the murder of Freda Burnell, Florence Little had repeatedly informed Jones of her being convinced of his guilt of the crime, although whether she had merely been joking with him is unknown.}}
With Jones's father's consent, the local [[Superintendent (police)|superintendent]], Henry Lewis, and a constable searched Jones's home at 8:30 a.m. the following day as Harold discreetly exited the family home.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 88</ref> Noting the trap-door to the attic was bloodstained despite evident attempts to clean it, the constable conducting the search entered the attic where he discovered Florence's body outstretched across the rafters. Also discovered in the police search of Jones's home were the bloodstained knife Jones had used to murder Florence, a small egg-saucepan filled with a mixture of blood and water beneath the sink over which he had cut the child's throat, a bloodstained plank of wood measuring 19 inches in length concealed beneath the family boiler, and a bloodstained table close to the entrance to the attic in which Florence's body had been concealed.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 89</ref>
Informed of the discovery in his attic, Phillip Jones left his property and performed a [[Citizen's arrest#United Kingdom|citizen's arrest]] on his son as he conversed with a friend in nearby Mitre Street. Jones then accompanied his father back to Darran Road, where he was placed under arrest.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 91</ref>{{refn|group=n|Upon performing this [[Citizen's arrest#United Kingdom|citizen's arrest]] on his own son, Herbert Jones stated: "I've got no money; I can't help you this time" before escorting his son to the family home.}}
When news of Jones's arrest for the suspected murder of a second young girl reached the local public, an irate crowd of approximately 500 people gathered outside the local police station, demanding his immediate release. In response, Superintendent Lewis addressed the crowd, stating: "I have found the body of the child in the attic of Harold Jones, foully murdered, and I have arrested Harold Jones. I think this is all I can tell you and it would help us if you disperse and go to your homes."<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 87</ref>
==Second murder inquest== On 11 July, an inquest into the death of Florence Little was formally opened. Again conducted by the deputy coroner for the district, the jury heard testimony on this date that Florence Little had effectively bled to death from the wound to her throat. Also to testify at the inquest was Florence's mother, Elsie, who stated that when she had knocked at the Jones residence on the date of her daughter's disappearance, it had taken Harold Jones (the sole occupant in the house at the time) a full two minutes to answer the door, with the explanation he had been bathing when she called. When she asked Jones whether he had seen her daughter, he had smiled before replying: "Florrie's been here, but went through the back way."
The inquest was adjourned until 23 July, with the jury subsequently reaching a unanimous verdict of wilful murder against Harold Jones after just 30 minutes' deliberation. When asked if he had anything to say in relation to this verdict and his being committed to again stand trial at Monmouthshire Assizes for a child murder, Jones—having taken copious notes of the court proceedings<ref>{{cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/28007232|title=A Welsh Horror. Two little Girls Murdered; A Boy's Confession|access-date=8 September 2018|newspaper=nla.gov.au|date=3 November 1921}}</ref>—reportedly jumped to his feet and proclaimed his innocence. He was again detained at Usk Prison to await trial.<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 178</ref>{{refn|group=n|Following Jones's acquittal for the murder of Freda Burnell, public opinion had elevated him to a status of wronged hero. According to some [[criminologist]]s and authors, the public reception he had experienced following his accusal and acquittal of Freda's murder had nurtured such a degree of [[vanity]] in Jones that he had simply murdered Florence in order to experience the same public reception and legal acquittal.}} {{quote box | quote = "I, Harold Jones, do confess that I [[Wilful murder|wilfully]] and deliberately murdered Florence Irene Little on 8 July, causing her to die without preparation to meet her God. The reason for doing so being a desire to kill." | source = Harold Jones's written statement, formally confessing to the murder of Florence Little. 17 September 1921.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 78</ref> | width = 32em }} While awaiting trial, Jones formally confessed to the murder of Florence Little via a written statement dated 17 September. In this statement, Jones described his [[Motive (law)|motive]] for the murder as being a "desire to kill".<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} p. 178</ref>
==Trial and conviction== The trial of Harold Jones for the murder of Florence Irene Little began at Monmouthshire Assizes on 1 November 1921. He was tried before Mr. Justice Bray, with the prosecution contending this murder had been primarily committed due to Jones having enjoyed being "a part of the public eye" due to the attention he had received following his arrest and acquittal of Freda's murder weeks earlier,<ref>''A Question of Evidence: The Casebook of Great Forensic Controversies, from Napoleon to O.J.'' {{ISBN|0-471-44014-0}} p. 139</ref> adding that he had made evident attempts to conceal evidence of the crime within his home after the murder.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/28007232|title=A Welsh Horror. Two little Girls Murdered; A Boy's Confession|access-date=8 September 2018|newspaper=nla.gov.au|date=3 November 1921}}</ref>
The trial lasted just one hour; Jones was ordered to be detained at [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|His Majesty's pleasure]] as because he was under 16 at the time of conviction, he could not be subjected to any form of [[Capital punishment in the United Kingdom|capital punishment]].{{refn|group=n|In 1921, a sentence of to be detained at [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|His Majesty's pleasure]] held a compulsory [[parole]] review every five years, although the judge at Jones's trial emphasised that in this instance, a parole hearing would only be held every 10 years.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 93</ref>}}
Shortly after Jones was escorted to prison to begin his sentence, a second written statement was read aloud to the court. This statement—also penned prior to his trial—read: "I, Harold Jones, wilfully and deliberately murdered Freda Burnell in Mortimer's Shed on 5 February 1921. The reason for this act was a desire to kill."<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 78</ref> [[File:Usk Prison, Maryport Street, Usk.jpg|thumb|right|[[HM Prison Usk]]. Jones was sentenced to be detained at [[At Her Majesty's pleasure|His Majesty's pleasure]] at this prison on 1 November 1921]] ==Aftermath== Harold Jones served 20 years of his imposed sentence of [[life imprisonment]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.kentonline.co.uk/dartford/news/i-know-who-killed-girl-158735/|title=Author Neil Milkins Says He Knows who Killed Girl in Wood in 1946|access-date=19 September 2018|newspaper=kentonline.co.uk|date=20 January 2018}}</ref> Against the recommendations of a [[psychiatrist]],<ref>''Exposing Jack the Stripper: A Biography of the Worst Serial Killer You've Probably Never Heard Of'' {{ISBN|978-1-492-21043-6}} p. 176</ref> he was released from prison on [[parole]] on 6 December 1941 at age 35, and subsequently joined the [[Merchant Navy#British Merchant Navy|Merchant Navy]]. At the conclusion of the [[World War II|Second World War]], Jones briefly resided in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]],<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 79</ref> although by 1948, he is known to have relocated to [[Fulham]], using the alias Harry Stevens. He later married and fathered a child.<ref>''Exposing Jack the Stripper: A Biography of the Worst Serial Killer You've Probably Never Heard Of'' {{ISBN|978-1-492-21043-6}} p. 176</ref>
Jones died of bone cancer in 1971.<ref>''The Who's Who of British Crime: In the Twentieth Century'' {{ISBN|978-1-445-63924-6}} pp. 177-179</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-45044159|title=Murdered Abertillery Girl's Niece Learnt About Tragedy in Book|access-date=11 September 2018|newspaper=BBC.co.uk|date=4 August 2018}}</ref> At the time of his death, he was employed as a night watchman and living under the alias of Harry Jones, although before he died, he told his wife the name Harold Jones should be placed upon his death certificate.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 95</ref>
Shortly after the murder of Florence Little, his employer, Herbert Mortimer, closed his shop and relocated with his family from Abertillery to an unknown location. Reportedly, this decision was made due to both a mixture of ostracization from locals regarding the false testimony he had delivered at Jones's trial for the murder of Freda Burnell, and his own guilt that this false testimony had enabled Jones to subsequently remain at liberty and kill again.<ref>''Dark Valleys: Foul Deeds Among the South Wales Valleys 1845 - 2016'' {{ISBN|978-1-473-86181-7}} p. 88</ref>
Both Freda Burnell and Florence Little were buried in Brynithel Cemetery. Their graves fell into a state of disrepair over the decades, although a 2017 appeal initiated by a local author named Neil Milkins to restore their graves and headstones raised more than £4,000, he having been inspired to do so after speaking to relatives of both girls, who were upset by the state of disrepair of the graves. The girls' graves were subsequently restored in 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-45044159|title=Murdered Abertillery Girl's Niece Learnt About Tragedy in Book|access-date=8 September 2018|newspaper=BBC.co.uk|date=4 August 2018}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox zoo |zoo_name = Jerusalem Biblical Zoo |logo = JBZ logo.JPG |logo_caption = Zoo logo |logo_width =83px |image = Jerusalem Zoo spider monkey.jpg |image_caption = A [[Geoffroy's spider monkey|black-handed spider monkey]] swings on a rope over the [[artificial lake]] at the zoo |image_width =200px |date_opened = 1940 |date_closed = |location = [[Malha]], [[Jerusalem]] |coordinates = {{Coord|31|44|58|N|35|10|37|E|display=inline,title}} |area = {{convert|62|acre|ha|adj=on}}<ref name="life">{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=112016 |title=A Life of Its Own |last=Stromberg |first=David |date=22 August 2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[The Jerusalem Post]]}}</ref> |num_animals = 2,200 (as of 2009)<ref name="attraction">{{cite web |url= http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=173247 |title=Animal Attraction |last=Yelinek |first=Aviel |date=16 April 2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> |num_species = 271 (as of 2009)<ref name="attraction" /> |members = [[World Association of Zoos and Aquariums|WAZA]],<ref name="waza_list"/> [[European Association of Zoos and Aquaria|EAZA]],<ref name="eaza_list"/> [[Israeli Zoo Association|IZA]],<ref name="iza_list"/> [[International Species Information System|ISIS]]<ref name="isis_list"/> |website = {{URL|http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/}} }} '''The Tisch Family Zoological Gardens in Jerusalem''' ({{lang-he|גן החיות התנ"כי בירושלים על שם משפחת טיש}}, {{lang-ar|حديقة الحيوان الكتابية في أورشليم القدس}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ḥadīqat al-Ḥaiwān al-Kitābīya Ūrushalīm al-Quds}}''), popularly known as the '''Jerusalem Biblical Zoo''', is a [[zoo]] located in the [[Malha]] neighborhood of [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]]. It is famous for its Afro-Asiatic collection of [[Biodiversity in Israel, the West Bank, and the Gaza Strip|wildlife]] many of which are ascribed in the [[Hebrew Bible]], as well as its success in [[Captive breeding|breeding]] [[endangered species]].<ref name="managers">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/zoo-managers-from-around-the-world-go-biblical-in-jerusalem-1.353398 |title=Zoo managers from around the world go biblical in Jerusalem |last=Lis |first=Jonathan |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=22 October 2011 |work=[[Haaretz]]}}</ref> According to [[Dun and Bradstreet]], the Biblical Zoo was the most popular [[tourist attraction]] in Israel from 2005 to 2007, and logged a record 738,000 visitors in 2009.<ref name="attraction" /> The zoo had about 55,000 members in 2009.<ref name="Tisch2009">{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemfoundation.org/uploads//Zoo%20report%202010.pdf |title=The Tisch Family Zoological Gardens Annual Report 2009 |year=2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726062702/http://www.jerusalemfoundation.org/uploads//Zoo%20report%202010.pdf |archive-date=26 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== History == [[File:Shulov2.jpg|left|150px|thumb|[[Aharon Shulov]] and his wife, Yocheved, holding a [[Pythonidae|python]].]]
The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo opened in September 1940 as a small "animal corner" on Rabbi Kook Street in central Jerusalem.<ref name="sbl">{{cite web |url=http://www.sbl-site.org/publications/article.aspx?articleId=579 |title=The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo |last=Greenbaum |first=Avraham |date=August 2006 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Society of Biblical Literature]]}}</ref><ref name="NY">{{cite web |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=travel&res=9B03EFD71639F935A35750C0A965948260 |title=Jerusalem's Modern Ark |last=Kammen |first=Michael |date=6 March 1983 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> The zoo was founded by [[Aharon Shulov]], a professor of [[zoology]] at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], [[Mount Scopus]]. Among Shulov's goals were to provide a research facility for his students; to gather animals, reptiles and birds mentioned in the Bible;<ref name="NY" /><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/?id=hW_fAAAAMAAJ&q=Aharon+Shulov&dq=Aharon+Shulov |title=Christian Victory |volume=56 |year=1982 |publisher=The Company |page=6}}</ref> and, as he wrote in 1951, to break down the "invisible wall" between the intellectuals on Mount Scopus and the general public.<ref>Shulov, Aharon (1980). ''The Leopard''. Jerusalem: The Jerusalem Zoo Educational Series, p. 13.</ref>
Early on, the zoo ran into several difficulties in its decision to focus on animals mentioned in the Bible. For one, the meaning of many names of animals, reptiles and birds in Scriptures is often uncertain; for example, ''nesher'' ({{lang-he|נשר}}), commonly translated as "eagle", could also mean "vulture".<ref name="sbl" /> More significantly, many of the animals mentioned in the Bible are now [[Extinction|extinct]] in Israel due to over-hunting, destruction of natural habitats by rapid construction and development, illegal poisoning by farmers, and low birth rate.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/life/religion/7003569.html |title=Doing Noah Proud |last=Grooters |first=Sarah |date=13 May 2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]]}}</ref> Zoo planners decided to branch beyond strictly biblical animals and include worldwide [[endangered species]] as well.<ref name="sbl" />
===Complaints from the neighbors=== [[File:Jerusalem Biblical Zoo 1940s.jpg|thumb|The zoo in the 1940s, probably on [[Shmuel HaNavi Street]]]]
The presence of the animal corner generated many complaints from residents in adjoining buildings due to the smell and noise, as well as the perceived danger of animal escapes. Due to the complaints, the zoo relocated in 1941 to a {{convert|4.5|dunam|hectare|adj=on}} lot on [[Shmuel HaNavi Street]]. Here, too, complaints were heard from the neighbors, but the zoo remained at this site for the next six years.<ref name="sbl" />
In 1947 the zoo, which by now had 122 animals,<ref name="NY" /> relocated to a plot of land on [[Mount Scopus]] provided by Hebrew University. It remained there from 1947 to 1950. Its occupancy coincided with the [[1948 Arab-Israeli War]] and the [[Siege of Jerusalem (1948)|siege of Jerusalem]], when food for the city's population was at a premium. Zookeepers resorted to hunting down stray dogs near garbage dumps in order to feed the [[carnivore|carnivorous]] animals. Many of the carnivores died anyway, and other, non-dangerous species had to be released.<ref name="sbl" />
As part of the [[1949 Armistice Agreements#With Jordan|Israel-Jordan Armistice Agreements of 1949]], access to Mount Scopus was restricted. The [[United Nations]] helped the zoo relocate<ref name="sbl" /> to a {{convert|15|hectare|ha|adj=on}} lot<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goisrael.com/Tourism_Eng/Articles/Attractions/The+Tisch+Family+Biblical+Zoo.htm |title=The Tisch Family Biblical Zoo |publisher=Israel Ministry of Tourism |accessdate=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117182422/http://goisrael.com/Tourism_Eng/Articles/Attractions/The+Tisch+Family+Biblical+Zoo.htm |archive-date=17 November 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in Givat Komuna, adjacent to the present-day neighborhoods of [[Romema]] and [[Ezrat Torah]]. According to Shulov, when the zoo arrived in Romema, only two [[Wolf|wolves]], one [[hyena]], one [[lion]] and one [[leopard]] were left.<ref name="sbl" /><ref>Shulov, Aharon (1981). ''The Wolf Shall Dwell with the Lamb: 40 years of the Jerusalem Biblical Zoo'' (in Hebrew). Jerusalem: Jerusalem Biblical Zoo, pp. 4–5.</ref>
The zoo remained in Romema from 1950 to 1991, becoming a beloved Jerusalem institution. About 30 percent of its attendance came from [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] families from northern Jerusalem and [[Muslim]] families from [[East Jerusalem]]—two population groups that normally do not participate in the city's cultural offerings.<ref name="born" /> The zoo grew to {{convert|28|acre|ha}} and more than 200 species, including most of the 130 animals mentioned in the Bible. Thanks to its [[Captive breeding|breeding]] program, 11 species that had disappeared from Israel were [[Reintroduction|reintroduced]] into nature reserves around the country, including the [[Syrian brown bear]], the [[addax]], and two types of [[fallow deer]]. Through gifts, trades with other zoos, and its success at breeding, the zoo's collection exceeded 500 animals by 1967. During the [[Six-Day War]], however, 110 animals were killed by [[Shrapnel shell|shrapnel]] and stray bullets.<ref name="NY" />
The zoo was administered by a [[nonprofit]] corporation with representatives from Hebrew University, the Jerusalem Municipality, and the Israeli [[Israeli Ministry of Tourism|Ministries of Tourism]] and [[Israeli Ministry of Education|Education]]. From a financial standpoint, however, the zoo had little money. Shulov, who retired as director in 1983,<ref name="NY" /> often served as director without pay. The zoo was also considered inferior to the zoos of Tel Aviv and Haifa.<ref name="sbl" />
[[File:Teddy Jerusalem Zoo.jpg|thumb|Teddy the [[Asian elephant|elephant]], named in honor of Jerusalem mayor and zoo fund-raiser [[Teddy Kollek]].]] Jerusalem mayor [[Teddy Kollek]], who took office in 1965, became one of the zoo's main supporters and fund-raisers through his [[Jerusalem Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=112016 |title=The Zoo's No. 1 Friend |last=Doron |first=Shai |date=4 February 2007 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> Kollek promoted the idea of moving the zoo to a larger location and upgrading it to a state-of-the-art institution, as well as a tourist site that would appeal to secular and religious [[Jews|Jewish]] families and [[Arab]] families alike.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://venetec.com/Israel/ |title=Israel |year=2010 |publisher=Price Family Charitable Fund |accessdate=28 November 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Around 1990, under the auspices of the Jerusalem Foundation, the Tisch family of New York agreed to pay $5 million toward the $30 million cost of the project. Another $10 million was raised through sale of the lot in Romema, which was converted to housing. The Jerusalem municipality, the Israel Ministry of Tourism, the Jerusalem Foundation, and private sponsors also contributed.<ref name="born" /> The zoo closed its site in Romema in 1991 and reopened in the [[Malha]] valley, {{convert|7|km}} southwest of the city center,<ref name="born" /> in 1993.<ref name="sbl" />
== The zoo today == [[File:Jerusalem Zoo lake.jpg|thumb|View of the [[artificial lake]], with the [[siamang]] exhibit at left]]
The zoo, renamed the Tisch Family Zoological Gardens in Jerusalem, but still called the Jerusalem Biblical Zoo by the general public, opened for a preview period on 28 February 1993. It officially opened on 9 September 1993.<ref name="about">{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11017.php |title=About the Zoo |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo |year=2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
===Design and layout=== Designed by Miller-Blum & Associates Landscape Architects, and constructed by the [[Moriah Jerusalem Development Corporation]],<ref name="about" /> the zoo sits on {{convert|62|acre|ha}} in a valley surrounded by the hillside neighborhoods of [[Malha]] and [[Givat Masua]].<ref name="life" /> The park is landscaped with trees and shrubs native to Israel, many of which are mentioned in the Bible.
[[File:Jerusalem Zoo train.jpg|left|thumb|The zoo train]] The zoo is built on two main levels. A motorized train takes visitors on a circular route from the lower level to the upper level. The entire park is [[wheelchair-accessible]]; each train can also accommodate one wheelchair.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadsarah.org/index.asp?id=162 |title=The Biblical Zoo in Jerusalem – An Exciting Experience for Everyone |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Yad Sarah]]}}</ref>
The centerpiece of the lower level is an [[artificial lake]] which includes two islands of monkey exhibits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_sys/picture/atarim/site_form_atar_eng.asp?site_id=18&pic_cat=4&icon_cat=6&york_cat=7 |title=Biblical Zoo – The Tisch Family Zoological Gardens |date=22 March 2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jerusalem Municipality |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110106121612/http://www.jerusalem.muni.il/jer_sys/picture/atarim/site_form_atar_eng.asp?site_id=18&pic_cat=4&icon_cat=6&york_cat=7 |archive-date=6 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The lake is fed by a series of pools and waterfalls,<ref name="about" /> beginning at an [[artificial waterfall]] called "Moses' Rock" (an allusion to the well of [[Miriam]] which provided water for the [[Israelites]] during their 40-year sojourn in the desert). Water is recycled and pumped back to Moses' Rock through an underground system.<ref name="born" />
At the western end of the park stands a two-story, boat-shaped wooden visitor's center meant to resemble [[Noah's Ark]]. It contains an auditorium, an art gallery, a gift shop, a snack bar, and computer stations providing information on animals mentioned in the Bible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jposttravel.com/Christianity-in-Israel/Bible-animals.html |title=Bible Animals are Still Found in Israel |last=Hecht |first=Aaron |year=2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124063034/http://jposttravel.com/Christianity-in-Israel/Bible-animals.html |archive-date=24 November 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[File:Jerusalem Zoo Sculpture Park.jpg|thumb|Phantasmagorical sculptures by French sculptor [[Niki de Saint Phalle]] in the Noah's Ark Sculpture Park.]] The zoo operates several snack bars and a coffee shop. Picnic tables and benches are situated throughout the park. There is also an animal-themed jungle gym for children and a sculpture garden containing 23<ref>{{cite web |url=http://designistdream.com/page/11/ |title=Where the Wild Things Art |date=4 November 2007 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=designistdream.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709014942/http://designistdream.com/page/11/ |archivedate=9 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> phantasmagorical animal sculptures decorated with stones, mirrors, and mosaics,<ref name="crowne" /> which double as climbing toys, designed by [[French people|French]] sculptor [[Niki de Saint Phalle]], together with an underground Noah's Ark sculpture designed by Swiss architect Mario Botta.<ref name="born" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ci.escondido.ca.us/events/califia/chronology.pdf |title=Niki de Saint Phalle Chronology (1930–2002) |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=ci.escondido.ca.us |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117065506/http://www.ci.escondido.ca.us/events/califia/chronology.pdf |archivedate=17 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Children can also view [[three dimensional|3D]] films of animals in a small theater near the entrance to the zoo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cruisecritic.com/ports/newport.cfm?ID=470 |title=Been There, Done That |year=2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Independent Traveler}}</ref>
===Animal exhibits=== The traditional zoo infrastructure of bars and cages has been replaced by open areas separated from the public by trenches, [[moat]]s, bridges, and glass windows; outdoor exhibits also have an indoor shelter in case of bad weather.<ref name="born">{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/?id=bYsQvLkzRyoC&pg=PA96&dq=jerusalem+biblical+zoo+romema#v=onepage&q=jerusalem%20biblical%20zoo%20romema&f=false |title=Born Again |last=Oestermann |first=Richard |publisher=Gefen Books |date=June 1999 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |isbn= 978-965-229-214-8 |pages=94–98}}</ref> The only areas in which the public has direct contact with the animals are [[Lemur]] Land, the "petting pool" at the Wet Side Story aquatic exhibit, and the children's zoo, where children can pet and feed [[pygmy goat]]s, [[sheep]], [[rabbit]]s and [[guinea pig]]s.
[[File:Jerusalem Zoo Arabian oryx.jpg|thumb|[[Scimitar oryx]] roam in an open reserve.]] Animals and birds reside in natural habitats, from an African savannah to a tropical rain forest to the underground world of mice and cockroaches. The [[lesser kestrel]] exhibit is designed as a house in Jerusalem's [[Musrara, Jerusalem|Morasha]] district, formerly a major nesting ground for these birds.<ref name="Tisch2009" /> Each animal or bird which is mentioned in the Bible has a biblical verse in [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[English language|English]] appended to its information sign.<ref name="askmen">{{cite web |url=http://ie.askmen.com/top_10/travel_top_ten/44c_travel_top_ten.html |title=Top 10: Zoos – Number 4: Jerusalem Biblical Zoo, Jerusalem, Israel |last=Marks |first=Harry |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[AskMen.com]]}}</ref>
Behind the scenes, the zoo operates an animal medical center with surgery, recovery and treatment rooms, a laboratory, and a [[quarantine]] unit where incoming animals and zoo animals being sent to other zoos are tested for diseases. This medical center cares for all zoo animals except the elephants, giraffes, rhinoceroses, hippopotamus, and bison, which are treated in their own exhibits.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11019.php |title=Zoo Hospital |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
The parking lot accommodates 500 vehicles.<ref name="born" /> The city named the street astride the zoo Derech Aharon Shulov (Aharon Shulov Way) after the zoo's founder.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koogle.co.il/English/Businesses/Zoos--Animal-Farms |title=Zoos and Animal Farms |publisher=koogle.co.il |accessdate=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009213241/http://www.koogle.co.il/English/Businesses/Zoos--Animal-Farms |archive-date=9 October 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Animal species=== As of 2009, the zoo housed 2,200 animals representing 271 different species: 60 fish species, 68 mammal species, 28 reptile species, 11 amphibian species, and 104 bird species. Many species were introduced only in the last few years, as the collection numbered 208 species in 2007.<ref name="attraction" />
===Food sources=== [[File:Jerusalem Zoo Nubian ibex.jpg|thumb|[[Nubian ibex]] at feeding time]]
The massive amount of fruits and vegetables consumed daily by the zoo's animals are acquired free of charge through an agreement Shulov worked out with Israeli companies that [[Terumat hamaaser|tithe]] their produce in accordance with [[Halakha|Jewish law]].<ref name="NY" /> During the days of the [[Temple in Jerusalem]], ''[[Heave offering|terumah]]'', a tithe on agricultural produce, was designated for the [[Kohen|kohanim]] (priests) and their animals. After the destruction of the Temple, the rabbis decreed that the tithed produce could not be used and had to be destroyed. The animals of the Biblical Zoo were symbolically sold to a [[Kohen]] so that this tithed produce could be given to them.<ref name=ohr>{{cite web|url=http://ohr.edu/judaism/nature-apikorsas/natur007.htm|title=The Torah Universe: Great Apes and Wild Men|last=Slifkin|first=Nosson|year=1999|publisher=[[Ohr Somayach, Jerusalem|Ohr Somayach International]]|access-date=28 November 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629133141/http://ohr.edu/judaism/nature-apikorsas/natur007.htm|archive-date=29 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jewishrootscx.netfirms.com/the_biblical_tithe.htm |title=The Biblical Tithe...Taught Correctly |last=Lyons |first=Craig |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jewish Roots |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215161221/http://jewishrootscx.netfirms.com/the_biblical_tithe.htm |archive-date=15 December 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The animals of the Biblical Zoo receive nearly a ton of the choicest fruits and vegetables every day<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/pleasure-hunting/.premium-1.535221 |title=Animal attraction|first=Ronit|last=Vered|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=11 July 2013|accessdate=15 September 2013}}(subscription)</ref> through a distribution handled by the local religious council.<ref name=ohr/> Meat consumed by the carnivores is furnished by [[kashrut|kosher]] butchers, [[veterinarian]]s, and [[fishermen]].<ref name="NY" /> Pruned branches from edible plants in the park, such as date palms, olive trees and carob trees, are also used for [[fodder]].<ref name="green">{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/var/360/312287-104.pdf|title=Green Team |last=Kaufman |first=Dr. Elizabeth |date=June 2009 |publisher=Profile (newsletter of the Tisch Family Zoological Gardens in Jerusalem)|accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
During [[Passover]], the entire zoo is [[chametz]]-free.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://myrehovot.info/eng/archive/2005_04_01_archive.html |title=Jerusalem Biblical Zoo is Kosher for Passover |last=Burge |first=Beverly |year=2005 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=myrehovot.info}}</ref> Four to six weeks before the holiday, the animal feed pellets are switched from wheat-based to rice-based ingredients, and after Passover they are gradually switched back to wheat-based.<ref name=kohn>Kohn, Batya. "The Zoo Doctor". ''[[Ami (magazine)|Aim!]]'', 9 Nisan 5777 (April 5, 2017), pp. 24–27.</ref>
== Themes and focus ==
===Wildlife conservation=== [[File:Syrian brown bears 01.jpg|thumb|[[Syrian brown bear]]s at the zoo]] [[File:Addax-Jerusalem-Biblical-Zoo-IZE-481b.jpg|thumb|[[Addax]] in the African Yard of the zoo]]
The zoo sees its primary goal as the conservation of [[endangered species]].<ref name="reintro">{{cite web |url= http://jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11046.php |title=Animal Reintroductions |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=jerusalemzoo.org.il}}</ref> These include animals mentioned in the Bible which are now extinct in Israel, such as the [[Asian lion]], the [[Syrian brown bear]], the [[Asiatic cheetah]], the [[Nile crocodile]], and the [[Persian fallow deer]].<ref name="fodor">{{cite web |url=http://www.fodors.com/world/africa-and-middle-east/israel/jerusalem/review-190726.html |title=Tisch Family Zoological Gardens |year=2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Fodor's]]}}</ref> It also includes endangered species worldwide, such as the [[Asian elephant]], rare species of [[macaw]],<ref name="fodor" /> the [[cockatiel]], the [[ibis]], and the [[golden lion tamarin]].
Towards that end, the zoo undertakes to [[Captive breeding|breed animals in captivity]] and, in some cases, reintroduce them to the wild. Through this program, the zoo has successfully increased the number of Persian fallow deer in Israel. This species was thought to be extinct in the 20th century until a small number of deer were located in [[Iran]] in 1956. In 1978, four of these deer were brought to Israel and have since increased to several hundred, with a major breeding colony at the Jerusalem Biblical Zoo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aronheller.com/documents/articles/ap/ASAP/asap%20-%20biblical%20zoo.htm |title=At the Zoo, Two-By-Two |last=Heller |first=Aron |date=8 March 2006 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707163112/http://www.aronheller.com/documents/articles/ap/ASAP/asap%20-%20biblical%20zoo.htm |archive-date=7 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A concurrent project to protect the [[Kleinmann's tortoise|Negev tortoise]] from extinction involves breeding from artificially-incubated eggs.<ref name="Tisch2007" />
There is a captive breeding programme for the blind [[cave shrimp]] ''[[Typhlocaris galilea]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The biology and ecology of the blind prawn, ''Typhlocaris galilea'' Calman (Decapoda, Caridea) |author=M. Tsurnamal |journal=[[Crustaceana]] |volume=34 |issue=2 |year=1978 |pages=195–213 |jstor=20103268 |doi=10.1163/156854078X00736}}</ref><ref name="Kloosterman">{{cite web|url=http://www.greenprophet.com/2013/05/blind-shrimp-bible-zoo-jerusalem/|title=Blind Shrimp Spared from Extinction at Bible Zoo in Jerusalem|last=Kloosterman|first=Karin|date=2013-05-06|work=Green Prophet|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref>
At the zoo's National Center for Artificial Incubation of Raptor Eggs, eggs of [[Bird of prey|raptor]]s that are either extinct or severely decimated in Israel are incubated from captive-breeding pairs.<ref name="Tisch2007">{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemfoundation.org/uploads/%5Ccoexistence%5Cfrom%20arts%20to%20sports%5Ctisch%20zoological%20gardens%5CZoo%202007%20Annual%20Report.pdf |title=Hey Deer, Have You Heard About the Happenings at the Tisch Family Zoological Gardens in 2007? |year=2007 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[griffon vulture]], an endangered species, is the subject of much research activity. The zoo has successfully mated vultures with crippled wings – a feat that [[Ornithology|ornithologists]] previously thought could not be accomplished because these birds could not balance themselves properly.<ref name="vultures">{{cite web |url= http://www.israel21c.org/technology/israeli-scientists-help-vultures-spread-their-wings |title= Israeli scientists help vultures spread their wings |date=6 June 2004 |publisher=Israel21c |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref> It has also used two male vultures to hatch and raise chicks from incubated eggs.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://sandiegojewishworld.com/israel/the_golan/gamla_nature_reserve/sd4-7griffon_vulture.htm |title= Preying for peace |publisher=San Diego Jewish Press-Heritage |date=7 April 2000 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |last=Harrison |first=Donald H.}}</ref> Additionally, the zoo participates in a countrywide breeding program coordinated by the Israel Nature and Parks Authority to increase the birth rate of griffon vultures in the wild.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/home/article.aspx?id=158327 |title=Waiting in the Wings |last=Pomerantz |first=Batsheva |date=22 October 2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref>
The zoo conducts a small ceremony each time it returns a bird to the wild. In 1996, for the release of a griffon vulture which it named "Freedom", the zoo invited the mother of captured [[Israelis|Israeli]] [[navigator]] [[Ron Arad (pilot)|Ron Arad]] to help release the bird.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sandiegojewishworld.com/israel/jerusalem/biblical_zoo/19981211-biblical_zoo.htm |title=Judaic Park: S.D. Zoo helps Israel in quest to return biblical animals to the wild |last=Harrison |first=Donald H. |date=11 December 1998 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=San Diego Jewish Press-Heritage}}</ref>
[[File:Asian Elephant and Baby.JPG|left|thumb|The year-old [[Gabi (elephant)|Gabi]] (left) with his mother Tamar in the elephant enclosure, January 2007.]] The zoo is considered a world leader and educator in reproductive intervention.<ref name="protecting">{{cite web |url= http://www.israel21c.org/environment/jerusalem-biblical-zoo-a-world-leader-in-protecting-endangered-species |title=Jerusalem Biblical Zoo a World Leader in Protecting Endangered Species |last=Eisen |first=Sarah K. |date=28 June 2007 |publisher=Israel21c}}</ref> It achieved a major success in December 2005 with the birth of [[Gabi (elephant)|Gabi]], the first [[elephant]] conceived in Israel through [[Artificial insemination#Artificial insemination in livestock and pets|artificial insemination]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=190086 |title=Israeli ‘aid ships’ carry 4-legged animals to Turkey |last=Lidman |first=Melanie |date=4 October 2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> In conjunction with a team from the Reproduction Management Institute for Zoo Biology and Wildlife Research of Berlin, zoo veterinarians impregnated one of their female elephants, Tamar, with [[sperm]] obtained from Emmett, a bull elephant in the [[Whipsnade Zoo|Whipsnade Animal Park]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]].<ref name="protecting" /> On 10 December 2005, Gabi's six-hour birth was viewed by over 350,000 people in 108 countries via [[Streaming media|live streaming]] on the zoo's website.<ref name="life" />
The zoo has also pioneered the use of animal birth control. It was the first to use a [[Tranquilliser gun|dart gun]] to implant a slow-release hormone into the thigh of a female giraffe; she is the daughter of the zoo's bull giraffe, and inbreeding is inadvisable. The zoo uses slow-release hormones to control its [[chimpanzee]] and [[mandrill]] populations, which are reproducing too quickly for the space they occupy; letting the animals multiply and sending family members to other zoos is unwise, according to veterinarians.<ref name="protecting" />
Newborn animals that are threatened or ignored by their parents are raised by the veterinary staff. On 31 December 2008, for example, a newborn tiger cub ignored by its mother was taken home by a staff member to be bottle-fed.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.zooborns.com/zooborns/jerusalem-biblical-zoo/ |title=One Big Kitten: Tiger cub at the Jerusalem Zoo |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=zooborns.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thewere.com/blog/2009/02/27/week-in-photos-tiger-cub-pancake-race-more/ |title=Feb 27 Week in Photos: Tiger Cub, Pancake Race, More |year=2008 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Interesting Things}}</ref> A newborn leopard rejected by its mother spent its days at the zoo and nights at veterinarians' homes for its first three and a half months of life.<ref name=kohn/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jawscience.webs.com/aprdrelishevakaufman.htm |title=Dr. Elizabeth (Elisheva) Kaufman |year=2009 |publisher=Jewish Alliance for Women in Science |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
The zoo also provides medical treatment for animals and birds injured in the wild.<ref name="Tisch2006">{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemfoundation.org/uploads/%5Ccoexistence%5Cfrom%20arts%20to%20sports%5Ctisch%20zoological%20gardens%5Cthe%20tisch%20family%20zoo%20-%202006%20report.pdf |title=Tisch Family Zoological Gardens – 2006 Report |publisher=Jerusalem Foundation |year=2006 |accessdate=28 November 2010 }}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The wildlife is either released back to their natural environment (if they are healthy enough) or placed in other zoos. In the late 2000s, an [[aviary]] was built for [[eagle owl]]s which the zoo is nursing back to health.<ref name="Tisch2007" />
===Public education=== [[File:Jerusalem Zoo snake exhibit.jpg|left|thumb|Children view a [[snake]] behind protective glass.]]
Public education is another prime focus of the zoo. According to Shai Doron, director-general of the zoo since 1993,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/magazine/the-human-zoo-1.314357 |title=The Human Zoo |last=Saar |first=Yuval |date=17 September 2010 |publisher=Haaretz|accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref> "Our moral right to exist comes from educating and raising the awareness of our visitors."<ref name="life" />
Many [[Israelis]], both Jewish and Arab, are not familiar with zoos and get "overexcited" at seeing the animals on display.<ref name="NY" /> Dozens of zoo personnel man the displays during peak holiday times to stop visitors from throwing food and other items at the animals. The animals do have a preference for [[Bamba (snack)|Bamba]], the popular children's peanut-and-corn snack (though it gives the monkeys [[diarrhea]]); other common projectiles include bottles, plastic bags, and children's shoes.<ref name="beastly">{{cite web |url= http://www.jpost.com/home/article.aspx?id=21496 |title=Beastly Behavior |last=Alexander-Hurst |first=Nina |date=11 May 2006 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> In 1997 a [[toco toucan]] was found dead in its cage next to pieces of [[avocado]], a known bird [[toxin]].<ref name="beastly" /> In 2006 a [[hippopotamus]] died after swallowing a tennis ball tossed into its enclosure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=20914 |title= Hippopotamus swallows ball, dies at Biblical Zoo |date=5 May 2006 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> Over the past decade and a half, the zoo staff claims that public awareness has improved.<ref name="beastly" />
Through visiting school groups, after-school groups, special-education groups and summer camps, children learn about and interact with the animals.<ref name="born" /> Educational activities for children, including the zoo's own youth movement, promote interracial encounters between Arab and Jewish youth.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goisrael.com/Tourism_Eng/Articles/Attractions/The+Tisch+Family+Biblical+Zoo.htm |title=The Tisch Family Biblical Zoo |publisher=Israel Ministry of Tourism |accessdate=28 November 2010 |year=2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117182422/http://goisrael.com/Tourism_Eng/Articles/Attractions/The+Tisch+Family+Biblical+Zoo.htm |archive-date=17 November 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The zoo also mounts a traveling workshop called the Zoomobile, which brings small animals in cages and a sound system carrying the sounds of larger animals to schools, hospitals, and other locations.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.zoonews.co.uk/IZN/328/IZN-328.htm |title=The Itinerant Ark: Insights from the Wandering Zoo |last=Ben-David |first=Na'ama Y. |volume=50 |issue=7 |date=October–November 2003 |publisher=International Zoo News |accessdate=28 November 2010 |journal= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308105615/http://www.zoonews.co.uk/IZN/328/IZN-328.htm |archive-date=8 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Environmental awareness=== [[File:Jerusalem Zoo Wet Side Story.jpg|thumb|An animated water droplet projected onto a cascade of running water "talks" to visitors at the Wet Side Story aquatic exhibit.]]
The zoo teaches [[environmentalism]] both in its exhibits and by personal example. Since 1997<ref>Dedication plaque at entrance to ecological maze.</ref> it has featured an "ecological maze"<ref name="crowne" /> – a short path meandering through high bushes with signs that highlight ecological challenges in Israel. In spring 2010 it unveiled a $1.5 million aquatic exhibit called "Wet Side Story"<ref name="beach">{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/features/everything-but-the-beach-1.291620 |title=Everything but the beach |last=Lis |first=Jonathan |date=23 May 2010 |publisher=Haaretz |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref> which stresses the importance of water conservation, ecology awareness, and water challenges in the [[Middle East]] and around the world.<ref name="Tisch2009" /> This exhibit displays rare and endangered marine life<ref name="beach" /> in 17 large [[aquarium]]s and three huge water tanks measuring 2 x 4 metres (7 x 14 ft). There is also an outdoor "petting pool" where visitors can touch and feed [[koi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.resistnet.com/group/istandwithisrael/forum/topics/if-pa-declares-state-israel?page=1&commentId=2600775%3AComment%3A1799042&x=1#2600775Comment1799042 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20110807162047/http://www.resistnet.com/group/istandwithisrael/forum/topics/if-pa-declares-state-israel?page=1&commentId=2600775:Comment:1799042&x=1%232600775Comment1799042#2600775Comment1799042 |dead-url=yes|title='Wet Side Story' Opens at Jerusalem Biblical Zoo |last=Julian |first=Hana Levi |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=resistnet.com }}</ref>
In keeping with its "green" policy, the zoo maintains its own [[sewage treatment]] system and uses [[Reclaimed water|recycled water]] to irrigate its gardens. Food and animal waste are mixed with plant material and placed in large [[compost]] piles; the compost is used to [[Fertilization|fertilize]] the trees and shrubs.<ref name="Tisch2009" /> The zoo sells its organic compost in the gift shop.<ref name="green" /> In 2006 receptacles for collecting used plastic drink bottles were installed next to each of the snack bars, and used batteries are collected at the gift shop.<ref name="Tisch2006" /> To reduce [[carbon emission]]s and traffic, the zoo schedules the use of delivery and security vehicles.<ref name="green" />
==Research== The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo participates in national and international research projects in the fields of zoology, biology, and environmental science, and publishes papers in journals and at scientific meetings.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Feline Central Retinal Degeneration in Captive Cheetahs (Acinonyx Jubatus) |last1=Ofri |first1=Ron |last2=Barishak |first2=Robert Y. |last3=Eshkar |first3=Gabi |last4=Aizenberg |first4=Itzhak |journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=101–108 |date=March 1996 |jstor=20095551}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.mivelle.hu/sambucol/Effect%20in%20Chimpanzees.pdf |title=The Effect of Sambucol on Flu-like Symptoms in Chimpanzees: Prophylactic and symptom-dependent treatment |last1=Burge |first1=Beverly |last2=Mumcuoglu |first2=Madeleine |last3=Simmons |first3=Tal |journal=International Zoo News |volume=46 |issue=1 |year=1999 |pages=16–19 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721111803/http://www.mivelle.hu/sambucol/Effect%20in%20Chimpanzees.pdf |archive-date=21 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://library.vetmed.fu-berlin.de/resources/global/contents/VET164623/EAZWV/Parijs%20PDF/Microsoft%20Word%20-%20Eshkar.pdf |title=Periodic Recurrent Keratitis in Asian Elephants |last1=Eshkar |first1=G. |last2=Avni-Magen |first2=N. |last3=Ofri |first3=R. |publisher=European Association of Zoo and Wildlife Veterinarians, Third Scientific Meeting |date=31 May – 4 June 2000 |accessdate=28 November 2010 }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://lib.bioinfo.pl/pmid:18432106 |title=Use of a sustained release preparation of clotrimazole to treat dermatophytosis in a siamang (Hylobates syndactylus) |last1=Avni-Magen |first1=Nili |last2=Elad |first2=Daniel |last3=Friedman |first3=Michael |last4=Gati |first4=Irith |last5=Kaufman |first5=Elizabeth |last6=Lavy |first6=Eran |journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine |date=March 2008 |volume=39 |issue=1 |pages=115–117 |doi=10.1638/2007-0018.1 |pmid=18432106 |access-date=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314020546/http://lib.bioinfo.pl/pmid:18432106 |archive-date=14 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=http://zoowildlifejournal.com/doi/abs/10.1638/2010-0004.1 |last1=Bakal-Weiss |first1=Meytal |last2=Steinberg |first2=Doron |last3=Friedman |first3=Michael |last4=Gati |first4=Irith |last5=Avni-Magen |first5=Nili |last6=Kaufman |first6=Elizabeth |last7=Lavy |first7=Eran |date=June 2010 |title=Use of a Sustained Release Chlorhexidine Varnish as Treatment of Oral Necrobacillosis in Macropus spp | journal=Journal of Zoo and Wildlife Medicine |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=371–373 |doi=10.1638/2010-0004.1 |pmid=20597238}}</ref> Through its Aharon Shulov Fund for the Study of Animals in Captivity, it also provides grants for research on animal welfare and husbandry, animal reintroduction, reproduction of endangered species, [[conservation genetics]], and exotic animal nutrition and medical care.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11400.php |title=List of research projects |publisher=Jerusalem Biblical Zoo |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref> The Fund is sponsored by Shulov's family, the Friends of the Zoo Association, and the Jerusalem Zoo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11047.php |title=Shulov Fund |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo |accessdate=28 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104100521/http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11047.php |archivedate= 4 November 2013 |df= }}</ref>
The zoo hosts academic seminars and student research at the Gabi Center, located in a {{convert|21|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility inside the main entrance. The center was named in memory of Dr. Gabi Eshkar, deputy director-general and chief veterinarian of the zoo for over 17 years, who was killed in an automobile accident in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11020.php |title=Gabi Center |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref>
===Affiliations=== [[File:Jerusalem Zoo flamingos.jpg|left|180px|thumb|[[Flamingo]]s at the zoo]]
The Jerusalem Biblical Zoo is a full member of the [[European Association of Zoos and Aquaria]] (EAZA).<ref name="eaza_list">{{cite web|url=http://www.eaza.net/membership/Pages/Zoos%20and%20Aquariums.aspx |title=EAZA Member Zoos and Aquariums |year=2010 |publisher=[[European Association of Zoos and Aquaria]] |accessdate=28 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819151758/http://www.eaza.net/membership/Pages/Zoos%20and%20Aquariums.aspx |archivedate=19 August 2010 |df= }}</ref> Zoo director-general Shai Doron is the only EAZA Council Member from Israel in the 2009–2012 season,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eaza.net/about/About%20EAZA%20Documents/Council_09-12.pdf |title=Council Members 2009–2012 |publisher=EAZA |accessdate=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720151033/http://www.eaza.net/about/About%20EAZA%20Documents/Council_09-12.pdf |archive-date=20 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> while general curator Shmulik Yedvab has been EAZA's [[European Endangered Species Programme]] project coordinator for the [[white-tailed sea eagle]] population of Europe and Asia since 1995.<ref name="protecting" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eaza.net/activities/cp/Pages/EEPs.aspx |title=Complete List of EEPs and ESBs |year=2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=EAZA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205074701/http://www.eaza.net/activities/cp/Pages/EEPs.aspx |archivedate= 5 February 2015 |df= }}</ref> The zoo is also a member of the [[World Association of Zoos and Aquariums]] (WAZA),<ref name="waza_list">{{cite web |url=http://www.waza.org/en/site/zoos-aquariums |title=Member Zoos and Aquariums |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[World Association of Zoos and Aquariums]]}}</ref> the [[Israel Zoo Association]] (which it helped form),<ref name="iza_list">{{cite journal |url= http://www.eretz.com/NEW/zoo1.shtml |title=Redefining Zoos |last=Gleit |first=Heidi J. |year=2010 |issue=105 |publisher=ERETZ Magazine |accessdate=28 November 2010}}</ref> and the [[International Species Information System]] (ISIS).<ref name="isis_list">{{cite web |url=http://forest.up.nic.in/ftikanpur/wltraining/international%20sps%20information%20system.pdf |title=Appendix F – ISIS Members |date=December 2004 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=International Species Information System |page=37 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721175202/http://forest.up.nic.in/ftikanpur/wltraining/international%20sps%20information%20system.pdf |archive-date=21 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Members of the veterinary staff belong to the American Association of Zoo Veterinarians, the European Association of Zoo and Wildlife Veterinarians, and the European Group on Zoo Animal Contraception.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.is/20120730014031/http://www.egzac.org/Admin/institutions.aspx |title=Alphabetized Institution List |year=2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=egzac.org |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712160429/http://archive/#46;is/20120730014031/http://www.egzac.org/Admin/institutions.aspx |archive-date=12 July 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Visitors and volunteers== [[File:Jerusalem Zoo petting.jpg|thumb|A boy tries to pet the [[goat]]s at the children's petting zoo.]]
A record 738,000 people visited the zoo in 2009.<ref name="attraction" /> The zoo does a brisk business in tourist groups, school groups, and summer camps: over 120,000 visitors arrived in groups in 2009. Included in the total are 63 groups of [[special needs|special-needs]] children, both Jewish and Arab,<ref name="Tisch2006" /> who participate in weekly sessions of [[animal-assisted therapy]].<ref name="Tisch2009" /> Total capacity in the park is 11,000 visitors.<ref name="crowne">{{cite web |url=http://www.afi-hotels.com/Crowne_Plaza_Jerusalem_Attractions |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707093526/http://www.afi-hotels.com/Crowne_Plaza_Jerusalem_Attractions |dead-url=yes |archive-date=7 July 2011 |title=Attractions in the Region: Jerusalem Biblical Zoo |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=[[Crowne Plaza]] }}</ref>
Over 50 volunteers assist zoo operations on a weekly basis.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/index.php?lang=en&act=page&id=11049&str=volunteers |title=Volunteering |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo}}</ref> The zoo's youth movement, called ''Tnuat Noach'' ({{lang-he|תנועת נח}}, "Noah's Movement"), involves teens aged 13–15 as volunteers in the children's zoo, small animal building, and bird and herbivores sections.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jewishsightseeing.com/israel/jerusalem/jerusalem_zoo/sd7-27-01jerusalem_zoo.htm |title= Zoo names a lake for Ellen Barnett |date=27 July 2001 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=San Diego Jewish Press-Heritage}}</ref> Members meet weekly with zoo staff and participate in hikes and expeditions in nature reserves.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/11041.php |title=The Zoo Youth Group |accessdate=28 November 2010 |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo}}</ref>
In March 2013 a Zoo Guide application for iPhone and iPad was released, which includes GPS navigation within the zoo, detailed information (written, pictorial and audio) about the animals, and a detailed daily schedule of feedings and events.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jerusalemzoo.org.il/len/apage/3208.php |title=Iphone App for the Jerusalem Biblical Zoo! |accessdate=29 March 2013 |publisher=Jerusalem Zoo}}</ref>
===Special events=== The zoo, which is open every day of the year except [[Yom Kippur]], [[Yom HaShoah]], and [[Yom Hazikaron]], schedules special activities on selected dates. Tree-planting activities are an annual [[Tu Bishvat]] tradition. On both days of [[Purim]] there is a parade, a family costume competition, and a [[tug of war]] between the entire [[Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.|Hapoel Jerusalem Basketball Team]] and one of the elephants (the elephant always wins). On Israel's [[Elections in Israel|Election Day]], zoo goers are encouraged to vote for their favorite animal.<ref name="Tisch2006" /> During the summer, the zoo conducts tours of [[Nocturnality|nocturnal]] animals in the wee hours of the night. It also schedules jazz concerts, juggling, and workshops during school vacations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.funinjerusalem.com/fun-list-categories/106-biblical-zoo.html49353-kids20with20sheep/?lang=en&font-size=smaller |title=Biblical Zoo |publisher=funinjerusalem.com |date=23 February 2010 |accessdate=28 November 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711054058/http://www.funinjerusalem.com/fun-list-categories/106-biblical-zoo.html49353-kids20with20sheep/?lang=en&font-size=smaller |archive-date=11 July 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Expansion plans== The [[Strategic planning|master plan]] for expansion is drafted by the zoo's main planning body, the International Zoological Committee, which is staffed by professionals in wildlife conservation, zoo management, education, tourism and economics. This committee convened in 1993, before the reopening of the zoo, and again in 1996, when it drafted plans for adding additional animal exhibits and visitor attractions by 2010.<ref name="life" />
New plans have been drawn up for an educational center and an exhibit called ''Yemei Bereishit'' (In the Days of Genesis) which replicates Biblical conditions and excludes all modern devices, including cell phones. The $30 million project will be paid for by private donations.<ref name="life" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} '''John de Ferrers, 1st Baron Ferrers of Chartley''' (1271, [[Cardiff]] – 1312) was the son of [[Robert de Ferrers, 6th Earl of Derby]] and Alianore de Bohun, daughter of Humphrey de Bohun and [[Eleanor de Braose]], and granddaughter of [[Humphrey de Bohun, 2nd Earl of Hereford]]. He was both [[Seneschal of Gascony]] and [[Lieutenant of Aquitaine]] in 1312, the year of his death.<ref>Marios Costambeys (2004), [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-9363 "Ferrers, John de, first Lord Ferrers of Chartley (1271–1312), magnate"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography''. Retrieved 11 November 2018.</ref>
